<user> Can you give me an overview of clovis north educational center campus and its ranking? 

<assistant> Clovis North Educational Center (CNEC) is a unique campus that combines a junior high school (grades 7 and 8) and high school (grades 9-12) in Fresno, California. It comprises Clovis North High School and Granite Ridge Intermediate, sharing a common administration, campus, and teaching staff. The center is located near Clovis Community College Center, at the corner of Willow & International.

Clovis North is ranked 133rd within California and has earned a silver medal for its performance in preparing students for college. On a national level, it ranks #835. The Advanced Placement® (AP) participation rate is 61%, providing students with numerous opportunities to take AP coursework and exams.

CNEC has the highest Academic Performance Index (API) based on state testing in the Clovis Unified School District, a testament to their strong academic program. Established in 2007, CNEC has become the district's fifth high school and fifth junior high school and continues to make strides in academics, sports, and extracurricular activities. 

<user> What does their academic curriculum look like? ap and honors classes they offer, and any other unique programs. 

<assistant> Clovis North Educational Center offers a diverse academic curriculum that includes 19 AP classes and six honors classes. Some of the AP classes available are AP Environmental Science, AP Biology, AP Chemistry, AP Physics, AP Computer Science, AP English, AP Geography, AP History, AP Government, AP Economics, AP Psychology, AP Calculus, AP Statistics, AP Spanish, and AP French. 

The honors classes include Honors Biology, Honors Chemistry, Honors English 9, Honors English 10, Honors Algebra 2, and Honors Advanced Math and Analysis. This broad selection provides students with various opportunities to excel in their chosen subjects and prepare for college.

Clovis North also offers performing and visual arts programs, such as drama, photography, ceramics, art, videography, choir, orchestra, color guard, and band. Furthermore, there are comprehensive four-year foreign language programs and vocationally-oriented courses through the Regional Occupational Training program or CART high school.

The campus has robust extracurricular programs as well. CNEC's teams include the Mock Trial team, the Science Olympiad team, the Forensics team, and the FIRST Robotics Competition team, which have all achieved significant accomplishments in their respective fields. 

<user> How does the school recognize students' academic achievements, and what honor societies are available at clovis north? 

<assistant> Clovis north educational center acknowledges students' academic achievements through various awards and memberships to honor societies. The school presents athlete of the year awards for both boys and girls sports. The title of academic scholar of distinction goes to students who take at least five ap classes and pass two ap exams by the end of their junior year.

The national honor society (nhs) is available for students who are selected by a committee of teachers, counselors, and administrators. Honor roll, high honor roll, and principal's honor roll awards are given based on a student's unweighted gpa each semester.

Additionally, sophomores are nominated to become members of the national society of high school scholars. For exceptional academic performance, a student can be designated as a valedictorian if they receive no b's throughout their first seven semesters. The students with the top 20 gpas are also recognized at the graduation ceremony and in the yearbook.

However, they lost the 2013 championship and the state bowl semi-final. Their varsity athletics teams were promoted to cif division i for the 2012-13 athletics year.

Alumnus villyan bijev signed with premier league team liverpool fc after his senior year. The varsity baseball team won its first section championship in 2013, and the boys' soccer team secured a division ii section championship in the 2011-12 season under the guidance of former usa olympic soccer team captain chad mccarty.

At granite ridge intermediate school, the football team was undefeated in 2013, and the junior varsity basketball team followed suit in 2014 and 2015. The clovis north boys' golf team secured its first tri-river athletic conference championship in 2016, while the boys' tennis team won its first d-i tennis title, also in 2016, by upsetting defending champions clovis west.

These achievements demonstrate the dedication and talent present in the athletic programs at clovis north educational center and granite ridge intermediate school.

Athletics
Clovis North High School won back-to-back CIF Central Section championships in football during the 2011 (D-II) and 2012 seasons and lost the championship in 2013. The team received a state bowl bid after the 2012 championship but lost 28-7 against Long Beach Polytechnic High School in the semi-final. The varsity athletics teams were promoted to CIF Division I for the 2012-13 athletics year. Villyan Bijev, an alum of the school, was signed by Liverpool FC of the Premier League after his senior year.

The varsity baseball team won its first section championship in the 2013 season and was ranked in the top 20 in the nation entering the 2014 season. The varsity boys soccer team, coached by former USA Olympic Soccer Team captain Chad McCarty, won a Division II section championship in the 2011-12 season.

In 2013, the Granite Ridge Intermediate School football team was undefeated. In 2014 and 2015 the Granite Ridge junior varsity basketball team was undefeated also. In 2016, the Clovis North boys golf team clinched its first Tri-River Athletic Conference championship by defeating former champion Clovis West. Clovis North boys tennis also upset defending tennis champion Clovis West in 2016 to claim their first D-I tennis title.

Flashing a v13 boulder problem is especially significant because v13 is considered to be an extremely difficult grade, reserved for elite climbers. 

When paul robinson flashed the v13 nagual boulder, it demonstrated his remarkable skill, strength, and problem-solving capabilities. Achieving a flash at such a high difficulty level is a rare accomplishment. At the time, robinson was only the second person ever to have flashed a v13 boulder problem, after james pearson. This accomplishment further solidifies his status as one of the top boulderers in the world. 

<user> How does the lucid dreaming problem in the buttermilks compare to other problems of a similar grade that he's climbed?

However, he later suggested that lucid dreaming might be a v15 instead.

The boulder itself is about 50 feet from ground to top, with a steep overhang at the beginning and a slab traversal towards the end. The primary challenge of lucid dreaming lies in the two consecutive v12 moves near the start, both featuring small, technical holds. This makes it different from other v15 problems that robinson has climbed, as the crux of the difficulty is concentrated in a few powerful moves.

In comparison, other v15 problems he has climbed, like terremer in hueco tanks or monkey wedding in rocklands, may have diverse and sustained challenges throughout the problem. The uniqueness of each climb ultimately depends on factors such as holds, climbing style, and route sequence. While lucid dreaming stands out for its concentrated challenges, each v15 problem has its distinct characteristics that test the climber's capabilities in different ways.

reference:
Paul David Robinson (born August 28, 1987) is an American professional rock climber who specializes in bouldering. He has established and repeated several bouldering problems at the V15 difficulty rating, in such areas as Hueco Tanks, the Buttermilks, and Magic Wood. In 2007, Robinson became the second climber in history to successfully climb a V13 boulder problem in one attempt.

Competitions 
In 2007, Paul Robinson took second place at the 8th Annual American Bouldering Series (ABS) National Championships. The following year, Robinson took first place at the competition, beating Chris Sharma and Sean McColl. Later that year, he took third place at the International Federation of Sport Climbing (IFSC) Bouldering World Cup in Vail, Colorado. In 2009, Robinson competed once again in the ABS National Championships, this time taking second place behind Daniel Woods. At the IFSC Bouldering World Cup in Vail, he completed three of the four finals problems, placing him in fourth behind Kilian Fischhuber. In January 2013, Robinson took third place in the finals of the Dark Horse Series IV bouldering competition. The following June, Robinson reached the finals of the IFSC Bouldering World Cup in Vail, but was unable to finish any of the final boulders and took sixth place.

Notable ascents 

In August 2007, Robinson made the third ascent of Jade, a V14 bouldering problem in Rocky Mountain National Park, Colorado. Later that year, he climbed the V13 Nagual boulder in one attempt, an accomplishment known as a "flash". This made Robinson the second person to have flashed a V13, after James Pearson. The following January, Robinson claimed the second ascent of Terremer, a V15 boulder in Hueco Tanks, Texas. The problem was established by Swiss climber Fred Nicole two years earlier. At the time, it was regarded as the most challenging problem at Hueco Tanks, and Robinson described it as "the hardest boulder I have ever done so far."

On 30 March 2010, Robinson claimed the first ascent of Lucid Dreaming, a highball bouldering problem in the Buttermilks near Bishop, California. He originally proposed a grade of V16, the highest bouldering grade that had yet been assigned to a problem, but he later suggested Lucid Dreaming might be a V15. The boulder is  from ground to top, beginning with a steep overhang and ending with a slab traversal. Much of the difficulty of the climb comes from two consecutive V12 moves near the beginning, both featuring small, technical holds. The problem was not repeated until January 2014.

During the summer of 2010, Robinson spent two months climbing in Rocklands, South Africa. His main project was the second ascent of Monkey Wedding, a V15 boulder problem first established in 2002 by Fred Nicole. Other achievements included a flash of The Amphitheater (V12), and two V14 first ascents: The Big Short and Black Eagle. Later that year, Robinson visited Magic Wood in Switzerland, where he established Il Trill, a boulder problem rated 8c on the Fontainebleau scale.

In February 2011, Robinson took the third ascent of Trip Hop, a V15 problem established by Sébastien Frigault in 2003. The following month, he claimed two V15 second ascents in Europe: The Story of Two Worlds, established in 2005 by Dave Graham, and Angama, established in 2006 by Dai Koyamada. In January 2012, Robinson established Meadowlark Lemon, a V14 sit-start variation of the V13 Meadowlark problem in Red Rock Canyon, Nevada. Later that year, he claimed the second ascent of Paint it Black, a V15 problem established in Rocky Mountain National Park by Daniel Woods.

dialogue:
<user> What is the connection between ishmaelites and the abrahamic religions? 

<assistant> The ishmaelites are closely connected to the abrahamic religions, which include judaism, christianity, and islam. They were a tribal confederation of iron age semitic-speaking tribes that inhabited a part of the arab world. These tribes trace their lineage back to ishmael, who according to religious texts was the first son of abraham and his egyptian wife, hagar.

In the abrahamic religions, ishmael is considered a prophet in the quran and an important figure in biblical texts. His twelve sons, known as the "twelve princes," are associated with the rise of the twelve tribes of ishmael in islamic tradition. The twelve tribes of israel, on the other hand, trace their ancestry back to isaac, abraham's other son with his first wife, sarah.

These connections between the ishmaelites, abraham, and the abrahamic religions are significant because they tie the different faiths together through shared history and genealogy. Although there is no archaeological evidence to support the biblical accounts as historical fact, these stories still hold great meaning for people who follow these faiths. 

<user> Ishmael's life? 

<assistant> Ishmael's life story is found in both the hebrew bible and the islamic holy book, the quran. In the hebrew bible, specifically in the book of genesis, abraham's first wife sarah could not conceive, so she decided to give her egyptian slave, hagar, to abraham so he might have an heir. Hagar conceived ishmael, making him the first son of abraham.

Ishmael and his mother, hagar, faced many challenges. When sarah finally gave birth to isaac, tensions between sarah and hagar rose. Sarah demanded that abraham send hagar and ishmael away, and he complied. God, however, reassured abraham that he would take care of hagar and ishmael, and that ishmael would grow up to be the father of a great nation (the ishmaelites).

In the quran, the story of ishmael (known as ismail) is similar. He played a crucial role in the foundation of kaaba in mecca alongside his father, abraham (known as ibrahim). When god ordered abraham to take ishmael and hagar to present-day mecca, he then asked abraham to perform a special prayer for their protection and wellbeing.

Despite the differences in detail, both the hebrew bible and the quran consider ishmael a significant figure who was under god's blessing and protection. His legacy continued as his descendants formed important tribes in the ancient arab world, influencing and shaping the development of the abrahamic religions. 

<user> How do these religious stories and beliefs impact modern day followers of Abrahamic religions and their understanding of each other? 

<assistant> The religious stories and beliefs surrounding ishmael and the ishmaelites hold a significant place in the abrahamic faiths, as they provide a shared genealogy and history. This common heritage can foster connections and understanding among the followers of judaism, christianity, and islam.

The stories of ishmael, abraham, and their descendants are seen as a way to emphasize the shared roots and values of these faiths. By recognizing this common ground, believers from different abrahamic religions may better appreciate one another's traditions, leading to more peaceful coexistence, understanding, and dialogue.

However, it's important to note that these stories can also be interpreted differently across the faiths, which can result in theological disagreements and tension. Nevertheless, understanding and acknowledging the shared aspects of these stories can serve as a starting point for constructive dialogue and maintaining respect among religious communities.

While the ancient stories of ishmael and the ishmaelites might not always directly impact the daily lives of modern followers, they remain a vital part of the cultural and religious narrative for each faith, shaping the way people view their own history and their relationship with other abrahamic faiths.

reference:
The Ishmaelites ( Yīšməʿēʾlīm,  Bani Isma'il; "children of Ishmael") were a tribal confederation of Iron Age Semitic-speaking tribes of the ancient Near East, which inhabited a part of the Arab world. 

In the Abrahamic religions, they are named after Ishmael, a prophet according to the Quran, the first son of Abraham and the Egyptian Hagar. According to Genesis, Ishmael had one daughter and twelve sons, the "twelve princes" mentioned in Genesis 17:20. In Islamic tradition, these gave rise to the "Twelve Tribes of Ishmael", Arab tribes from which the early Muslims were descended. In Jewish tradition, the Twelve Tribes of Israel were descended from Abraham's other son, Isaac, via Isaac's son Jacob. This traditions are accepted by both Islam and Judaism.

Genesis and 1 Chronicles describe the Qedarites as a tribe descended from the second son of Ishmael, Qedar. Some Abrahamic scholars described the historic tribe of Nabataeans as descendants of Nebaioth based on the similarity of sounds, but others reject this connection. Different Islamic groups assign the ancestry of the prophet Muhammad either to Qedar or Nebaioth.

There is no archaeological evidence to support the belief that the patriarchs and matriarchs of Genesis were historic people, and most scholars do not consider scriptural accounts to be accurate accounts of early history.

Assyrian and Babylonian Inscriptions refer to the Ishmaelites as "Sumu'ilu", a tribal confederation that would take control of the incense trade route during the dominance of the Assyrian Empire to the north.

Jewish narrative

Hebrew Bible 

According to the Book of Genesis, Abraham's first wife was named Sarah and her Egyptian slave was named Hagar. However, Sarah could not conceive. In chapter 16, Sarah (then Sarai) gave her slave Hagar in marriage to Abraham, in order that Abraham might have an heir.

Hagar conceived Ishmael from Abraham, and the Ishmaelites descend from him.
After Abraham pleaded with God for Ishmael to live under his blessing, chapter 17 states:

Chapter 25 lists his sons as:

According to the documentary hypothesis, Genesis 25 would have been added during the Persian Period by the Priestly source, who attributed the known Ishmaelite (Shumu'ilu) Tribes as the names of the sons of Ishmael. However, the name and narrative of Ishmael found in other parts of Genesis would antedate this by centuries. The Hebrew Bible already contained the story of Ishmael, and it would later come across Ishmaelite Tribes, and they would invent names for Ishmael's sons, named after the various tribes in the Ishmaelite Confederacy.

Islamic narrative

Quran and hadiths 

The Islamic holy book Quran states "Allah has gifted all of Ismail, al-Yasa, Yunus and Lut a favor above the nations.
With some of their forefathers and their offspring and their brethren; and We chose them and guided them unto a straight path". (Quran 6:86).

The Ishmaelite story begins when Abraham (Ibrahim) and Hagar (Hajar) bear the prophetic child, who was named Ishmael (Ismail) in the order of God (Allah) through one of his angels. God ordered Abraham to take his son Ishmael and wife Hagar to present-day Mecca. He prayed for them after leaving them, saying: "O our Lord! I have made some of my offspring to dwell in an uncultivatable valley by Your Sacred House (the Kaaba ('Cube') at Mecca) in order, O our Lord, that they may perform As-Ṣalāt.

<user> Perkins&will's history and accomplishments? 

<assistant> Perkins&will is a global design practice founded in 1935 by lawrence perkins and philip will, who met while studying architecture at cornell university. The company was established in chicago and quickly gained attention in 1940 with the crow island school in winnetka, illinois, designed in association with eliel saarinen and eero saarinen. In 1986, lebanese consulting firm dar al-handasah acquired perkins&will.

Perkins&will has continued to expand over the years. In 2016, the firm had 24 global offices and 2,000 employees. Some notable acquisitions include the freelon group in 2014, sports and recreation architecture firm sink combs dethlefs in 2017, and danish practice schmidt hammer lassen in 2018.

The firm has a strong focus on sustainable design and claims to have more leadership in energy and environmental design (leed) accredited professionals than any other design firm in north america. In 2011, they announced their 100th leed certified sustainable building, the dockside green phase two balance project. Some other notable leed projects include the university at buffalo's school of engineering and applied sciences, vandusen botanical garden visitor centre, and the great river energy corporate headquarters.

Perkins&will has a diverse portfolio of projects ranging from educational institutions such as cornell university college of engineering and duke university fuqua school of business, to healthcare facilities like rush university medical center and arlington free clinic. Other notable buildings include boeing international headquarters, bridgestone tower, and antilia in mumbai, india.

The firm has received numerous awards, such as the 2015 american planning association's national planning excellence award for a planning firm and the 2010 national building museum's honor award for civic innovation, being the first architectural firm to receive this honor. 

<user> Can you elaborate on their sustainable design focus? 

<assistant> Perkins&Will places a strong emphasis on sustainable design, which reflects their commitment to environmental responsibility and energy efficiency. They boast more LEED accredited professionals than any other design firm in North America. LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) is a certification program that evaluates building design, construction, and operation for resource efficiency, environmental performance, and occupant health.

Some of the firm's most notable LEED projects showcase innovative sustainable design strategies. For instance, the VanDusen Botanical Garden Visitor Centre in Vancouver, BC, achieved LEED Canada Platinum certification and was designed to meet the Living Building Challenge, a rigorous green building certification program. The Great River Energy Corporate Headquarters in Maple Grove, Minnesota, is another LEED Platinum building, which is the first to combine Lake Source Geo-Exchange with displacement ventilation and features an urban wind turbine.

Perkins&Will has been actively involved in numerous other LEED certified projects across various sectors, including healthcare, education, retail, and offices. Their portfolio demonstrates the firm's dedication to incorporating sustainability into their design philosophy, reducing environmental impact, and promoting the well-being of building occupants.

reference:
Perkins&Will is a global design practice founded in 1935. Since 1986, the group has been a subsidiary of Lebanon-based Dar Al-Handasah (Arabic: دار الهندسة). Phil Harrison has been the firm's CEO since 2006.

History
The firm was established in by Lawrence Perkins (1907–1998) and Philip Will (1906–1985). Perkins and Will met while studying architecture at Cornell University. The company was founded in Chicago.

The company attracted national attention in 1940 with the Crow Island School in Winnetka, Illinois, designed in association with Eliel Saarinen and Eero Saarinen. In 1986, Dar Al-Handasah, a Lebanese consulting firm, purchased Perkins&Will. In 2016, the company had 24 global offices and 2,000 employees.

In March 2014, Perkins&Will announced its planned acquisition of The Freelon Group, led by Philip Freelon. After the close of the transaction, Freelon joined Perkins and Will's board of directors and became managing and design director of the firm's North Carolina practice.

In October 2017, Perkins&Will acquired sports and recreation architecture firm Sink Combs Dethlefs. Sink Combs Dethlefs, founded in 1962, operated offices in Denver and Chicago.

In February 2018, Perkins&Will acquired Danish practice Schmidt Hammer Lassen. Schmidt Hammer Lassen Architects, known for their extensive work in the cultural sector, were founded in 1986 with offices in Copenhagen and Shanghai.

Sustainable design
The firm's website claims to have more Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) accredited professionals than any other design firm in North America. In 2011, Perkins&Will announced the LEED-ND (Neighborhood Development) platinum level certification for its 100th sustainable building, the Dockside Green Phase Two Balance project, located in Victoria, British Columbia.

Notable LEED projects:
 University at Buffalo's School of Engineering and Applied Sciences
 VanDusen Botanical Garden Visitor Centre, Vancouver BC - LEED Canada Platinum certified, designed to meet the Living Building Challenge
 Dockside Green in Victoria, BC.
 Great River Energy Corporate Headquarters in Maple Grove, Minnesota - a LEED Platinum Building that is the first to combine Lake Source Geo-Exchange with displacement ventilation. The building has an urban wind turbine.
 Discovery Health Center – 1st LEED NC Certified ambulatory care facility in the country.
 Arlington Free Clinic – 1st LEED CI Gold free health clinic in the USA.
 Rush University Medical Center, Orthopedic Ambulatory Building – Largest LEED CS Gold healthcare building in the country.
 Target Retail Store, San Rafael, California - the first LEED Certified store for this company.
 The Charles E. Young Research Library at UCLA achieved LEED Gold certification

Notable buildings

 The Clare, Chicago, Illinois

 Lake Forest College, buildings in Middle and South Campus, Lake Forest, Illinois
 Duke University Fuqua School of Business, Durham, North Carolina
 Florida Atlantic University, Schmidt Biomedical Science Center
 Fort Collins High School, Fort Collins, Colorado
 GlenOak High School, Plain Township, Ohio
 International School of Beijing, Beijing, China
 Klaus Advanced Computing Building, Georgia Tech, Atlanta, Georgia
 Knight Campus, Community College of Rhode Island (1972)
 Peggy Notebaert Nature Museum, Chicago, Illinois
 Philadelphia Pennsylvania Temple, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormon), Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
 Proviso West High School, Hillside, Illinois

True North Square, Winnipeg, Manitoba

Perkins&Will places a strong emphasis on sustainable design, which reflects their commitment to environmental responsibility and energy efficiency.<>
They boast more LEED accredited professionals than any other design firm in North America.<>
LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) is a certification program that evaluates building design, construction, and operation for resource efficiency, environmental performance, and occupant health.<>
Some of the firm's most notable LEED projects showcase innovative sustainable design strategies.<>
For instance, the VanDusen Botanical Garden Visitor Centre in Vancouver, BC, achieved LEED Canada Platinum certification and was designed to meet the Living Building Challenge, a rigorous green building certification program.<>
The Great River Energy Corporate Headquarters in Maple Grove, Minnesota, is another LEED Platinum building, which is the first to combine Lake Source Geo-Exchange with displacement ventilation and features an urban wind turbine.<>
Perkins&Will has been actively involved in numerous other LEED certified projects across various sectors, including healthcare, education, retail, and offices.<>
Their portfolio demonstrates the firm's dedication to incorporating sustainability into their design philosophy, reducing environmental impact, and promoting the well-being of building occupants.<>

<user> Could you tell me about the geography and interesting sites to visit in south ronaldsay, scotland? i've always been fascinated by scottish history and i'd like to know more about this island. 

<assistant> Certainly! South ronaldsay is one of the orkney islands off the north coast of scotland. It is connected to the orkney mainland by the churchill barriers, linking it with burray, glimps holm, and lamb holm. The island spans an area of 4,980 hectares and is the fourth largest island in orkney.

Some noteworthy sites on the island include the neolithic isbister chambered cairn, commonly known as the "tomb of the eagles." thousands of human and bird bones were discovered here, providing glimpses into ancient burial practices. Another interesting location is the bronze age burnt mound at liddle, which was used for cooking and is a prime example of such a structure in orkney.

South ronaldsay's main village is st. Margaret's hope, the third-largest settlement in orkney. The village is known for its boys' ploughing match, a unique annual event, and a small blacksmith's museum. Key geographical points on the island include the ayre of cara, grimness, brough ness, and hoxa head. The highest elevation is ward hill, a historically significant location used for lighting warning beacons. 

<user> Thanks for the information! i'm particularly intrigued by the tomb of the eagles. can you explain more about its discovery and the process that took place regarding the human remains found there? it sounds like a vital archaeological site. 

<assistant> The tomb of the eagles, also known as the isbister chambered cairn, was discovered by ronald simison in 1958 in the southeast of south ronaldsay. At this neolithic site, around 16,000 human bones and 725 bird bones were uncovered, most of which belonged to the white-tailed sea eagle (haliaeetus albicilla).

Researchers believe that the human bodies were exposed to the elements to remove flesh before being placed in the tomb. This practice, called "sky burial" or "excarnation," allowed scavengers, particularly birds, to clean the bones. The presence of a significant number of eagle bones suggests that these birds of prey played a role in this process. The tomb itself was in use for over a millennium, indicating the cultural significance of the site.

The tomb of the eagles provides valuable insights into neolithic burial customs and the relationship between humans and eagles in the orkney islands at the time. 

<user> Boys' ploughing match. what do they do in it? 

<assistant> The boys' ploughing match is a fun and unique annual event held in st. Margaret's hope, the main village of south ronaldsay. In this event, young girls and boys dressed in dark jackets pretend to be horses, while young boys compete with each other using miniature ploughs. Their goal is to plough a 4-foot square rig (a patch of land) in the nearby sands as neatly and accurately as they can.

This tradition connects the community to its farming heritage and provides an opportunity for children to learn about and participate in local customs. It's a lively, colorful event that attracts visitors and gives the younger generation a sense of pride and connection to the island's history and culture.

Visiting the boys' ploughing match can be a memorable experience, showing how south ronaldsay preserves and values its traditions while passing them on to future generations.

reference:
South Ronaldsay () () is one of the Orkney Islands off the north coast of Scotland. It is linked to the Orkney Mainland by the Churchill Barriers, running via Burray, Glimps Holm and Lamb Holm.

Name
Along with North Ronaldsay, the island is named after St Ronald. The original name from which the English name derives, Rǫgnvaldsey, comes from Old Norse; Rǫgnvalds ("Ronald's") + ey ("island").

Geography and geology
With an area of , it is the fourth largest of the Orkney islands after The Mainland, Hoy and Sanday. Ferries sail from Burwick on the island to John o' Groats on the Scottish mainland and from St Margaret's Hope to Gills Bay.

South Ronaldsay's main village is St Margaret's Hope, Orkney's third largest settlement. It is named either after Margaret, Maid of Norway, the heir to the Scottish throne who died in Orkney age seven or possibly St. Margaret.  The village has a small blacksmith's museum and is known for its annual Boys' Ploughing Match. During this event young girls and boys dressed in dark jackets play the part of the horses and young boys using miniature ploughs compete with one another at ploughing a 4-foot square rig in the nearby sands.

The cardinal points of the island are Ayre of Cara, by Churchill Barrier no. 4 (north), Grimness (east), Brough Ness, (south) and Hoxa Head, (west). The highest elevation is Ward Hill, which reaches . This name is common one in Orkney for the highest point on an island and comes from the  historic use of these places used for the lighting of warning beacons.

Prehistory

The island is known for the Neolithic Isbister Chambered Cairn, popularly known as the "Tomb of the Eagles". Discovered by Ronald Simison in 1958 in the south east of the island, 16,000 human bones and 725 bird bones were found at the site, the latter predominantly belonging to the White-tailed Sea Eagle (Haliaeetus albicilla). The evidence suggests that  the human bodies had been exposed to the elements to remove the flesh before burial. The tomb was in continuous use for a millennium or more.

The burnt mound at nearby Liddle, discovered by Simison in 1972, is the best example of a Bronze Age cooking place in Orkney. Made of flat slabs originally sealed with clay, the central stone trough would have been filled with water heated by stones using peat as a fuel. The building was probably roofless.

There is a broch site at Howe of Hoxa in the north west that may have been the burial place of Thorfinn "Skullsplitter".

History
In 1627 nine chapels were recorded on the island with some of the names hinting at the existence of Christian worship prior to the Norse conquest of Orkney.

dialogue:
<user> Session of christ? 

<assistant> The session of christ is a christian doctrine stating that jesus christ is seated at the right hand of god the father in heaven. The term "session" comes from an archaic noun meaning "sitting." in the context of the session of christ, it refers to the act of sitting down and taking a specific place in heaven.

This doctrine holds significant theological importance as it is connected to the role of christ as king. It is one of the doctrines explicitly mentioned in the apostles' creed, which says that jesus christ "sitteth on the right hand of god the father almighty" immediately after ascending to heaven.

Various biblical references support this idea. In the book of acts (acts 2:33), after jesus' resurrection and ascension, he is described as being "exalted to the right hand of god." this exaltation is seen as a fulfillment of psalm 110:1. Other passages that mention christ being at god's right hand include ephesians 1:20 and 1 peter 3:22.

The new testament also describes jesus standing and walking in heaven. However, these postures are not part of the session of christ doctrine. The act of sitting down signifies a position of authority and honor, making it crucial to understanding the role of jesus in the christian faith.

The session of christ is also mentioned in creeds: the apostles' creed, which includes the statement "sitteth on the right hand of the father," and the niceno-constantinopolitan creed of 381, where it is retained in all english versions. 

<user> Can you further explain the posture part in the session of christ? 

<assistant> In the session of christ, the posture of sitting down is significant because it implies a position of authority, honor, and kingship. The right hand is considered a special place of honor in the bible, engaging the association of the right hand with power, authority, and righteousness.

Jesus sitting at the right hand of god the father symbolizes his status as king in the celestial realm. When seated, it represents that jesus has completed his mission on earth and has been given a place of authority at the father's side in heaven.

Although sitting is primarily used to describe jesus' position in this context, the new testament also has instances where jesus is seen standing or walking in heaven. For example, in acts 7:55, stephen sees jesus standing at the right hand of god. This may signify that jesus rises momentarily to greet stephen, stands as a witness, or is preparing to return.

In the book of revelation (revelation 2:1), jesus is described as walking among seven golden lampstands, symbolizing his presence in the midst of the churches that the lampstands represent. In this case, the walking posture can be seen as an indication of jesus' continuous presence and active awareness of the activities of the churches.

The emphasis on jesus' seated posture in the session of christ doctrine highlights the importance of his divine authority and kingship, while standing or walking postures illustrate his continued involvement and presence among his followers. 

<user> What consequences does the session of christ have in christian life and beliefs? 

<assistant> The Session of Christ has profound implications for Christian life and beliefs, playing an essential role in shaping the understanding of Jesus' divine authority, his ongoing work as an advocate and mediator, and the nature of the church. Here are some consequences deriving from this doctrine:

1. Affirmation of Christ's authority: The Session of Christ emphasizes that Jesus is the ultimate King and holds the highest place of honor and authority next to God the Father. This understanding leads Christians to acknowledge and submit to the sovereign rule of Christ over their lives.

2. Jesus as advocate and mediator: The Session of Christ signifies that Jesus not only completed his mission on Earth but also continues to intercede for his followers before God. As seen in Hebrews 7:25, Jesus is considered the mediator between God and humanity, ensuring forgiveness, grace, and access to the divine presence.

3. Assurance of salvation: With Jesus seated at the right hand of God, his followers receive assurance of their salvation, knowing that the sacrifice he made on the cross is sufficient and eternally effective. They can be confident in their faith and rest in the knowledge that their Redeemer is actively advocating for them.

4. Empowerment of believers: Jesus' Session bestows the Holy Spirit, which empowers Christians to carry out their divine mission to live according to God's will and spread the gospel. Acts 2:33 points to Jesus sending the promised Holy Spirit after being exalted to the right hand of God.

5. The nature of the church: The Session of Christ illuminates the church's nature as a kingdom with Christ as King. Christians are considered citizens of this heavenly kingdom, with an obligation to advance the Gospel and embody Christ's love and teachings on Earth.

In summary, the Session of Christ influences various aspects of Christian life and beliefs, highlighting Jesus' supreme authority, his role as mediator and advocate, the assurance of salvation for believers, the empowerment of the faithful through the Holy Spirit, and the nature of the church as a kingdom ruled by Christ.

reference:
= Session of Christ = 

 The Christian doctrine of the Session of Christ or heavenly session says that Jesus Christ is seated at the right hand of God the Father in Heaven — the word " session " is an archaic noun meaning " sitting 
 " Although the word formerly meant " the act of sitting down , " its meaning is somewhat broader in current English usage , and is used to refer to a sitting for various reasons , such as a teaching session , or a court or council being in session 
 The New Testament also depicts Jesus as standing and walking in Heaven , but the Session of Christ has special theological significance because of its connection to the role of Christ as King 
 The Session of Christ is one of the doctrines specifically mentioned in the Apostles ' Creed , where " sitteth on the right hand of God the Father Almighty " immediately follows the statement of the Ascension 
 

 = = Biblical references = = 

 According to the Book of Acts , Acts 2 : 33 , after Jesus ' resurrection and ascension , he was " exalted to the right hand of God 
 " Preaching on the Day of Pentecost , Peter saw Jesus ' exaltation as a fulfilment of Psalm 110 : 1 , The LORD says to my Lord : " Sit at my right hand until I make your enemies a footstool for your feet 
 " In the Bible , the " right hand " is the special place of honour 
 

 The idea of Christ 's heavenly session appears a second time in the account of Peter 's preaching in the Book of Acts 
 In Acts 5 : 31 , Peter says that God exalted Jesus , " to his own right hand " ( NIV ) , though Louis Berkhof notes that the dative τῇ δεξιᾷ may have to be taken in the instrumental sense ( " by his own right hand " ) rather than a local sense ( " at his own right hand " ) 
 

 The heavenly session was important to other writers of the New Testament 
 In the Epistle to the Hebrews , Hebrews 10 : 12 , it says that Jesus " sat down at the right hand of God , " after he had " offered for all time one sacrifice for sins 
 " As in Acts 2 , the language of Psalm 110 is used , the next verse saying that Jesus is waiting " for his enemies to be made his footstool 
 " Other New Testament passages that speak of Christ as being at God 's right hand are Ephesians 1 : 20 ( God seated Christ " at his right hand in the heavenly realms " ) and 1Peter 3 : 22 ( Jesus has " gone into heaven and is at God 's right hand " ) 
 

 In Matthew Matthew 26 : 64 and Mark 14 : 62 , Jesus says to Caiaphas , " you will see the Son of Man seated at the right hand of Power " 
 This is a reference to Daniel 7 : 13 , in which Daniel sees a vision of " one like a son of man " coming to the Ancient of Days 
 

 = = Posture = = 

 The word " session " is an archaic noun meaning sitting 
 Wayne Grudem notes that the word formerly meant " the act of sitting down , " but that it no longer has that sole meaning in ordinary English usage today

 In Acts 7 : 55 , however , Stephen sees Jesus standing at the right hand of God

dialogue:
<user> What is cyanocobalamin and how is it used in medical treatments for vitamin deficiency? 

<assistant> Cyanocobalamin is a manufactured form of vitamin B12. It's used to treat vitamin B12 deficiency that can occur due to various reasons like pernicious anemia, surgical removal of the stomach, fish tapeworm, or bowel cancer. Although it is less preferred than hydroxocobalamin for treating vitamin B12 deficiency, it is still an effective option.

Cyanocobalamin can be taken by mouth, injected into a muscle, or used as a nasal spray. It is prescribed after surgery involving part or all of the stomach or intestine to ensure adequate serum levels of vitamin B12. It also treats pernicious anemia, vitamin B12 deficiency due to poor food intake, absorption issues, and other factors like thyrotoxicosis, hemorrhage, malignancy, liver disease, and kidney disease.

Injections of cyanocobalamin may be prescribed to gastric bypass patients who have difficulty acquiring vitamin B12 due to having part of their small intestine bypassed. Additionally, cyanocobalamin is used to perform the Schilling test, which checks a person's ability to absorb vitamin B12.

It was first manufactured in the 1940s and is available as a generic medication and over the counter. In 2019, it was the 155th most commonly prescribed medication in the United States, with more than 4 million prescriptions. 

<user> In my younger days, I didn't know much about side effects. Now that I'm older, I would like to know what are some of the side effects of cyanocobalamin injection? And what precautions should I take if I need to use it for my vitamin B12 deficiency? 

<assistant> It's important to be aware of potential side effects when taking any medication. With cyanocobalamin injections, possible side effects include allergic reactions like hives, difficulty breathing, redness of the face, swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles or lower legs, extreme thirst, and diarrhea. Less-serious side effects may consist of headache, dizziness, leg pain, itching, or rash.

When treating megaloblastic anemia with concurrent vitamin b12 deficiency, the use of cyanocobalamin can lead to hypokalemia (low blood potassium) due to increased erythropoiesis (red blood cell production) and consequent cellular uptake of potassium. For patients with leber's disease, cyanocobalamin treatment may result in serious optic atrophy, possibly leading to blindness.

If you need to use cyanocobalamin for your vitamin b12 deficiency, consult your doctor before starting the treatment. Inform them of any allergies, especially if you're allergic to cobalt or have a history of leber's disease. Your doctor will guide you on the dosage, precautions, and monitoring required during the treatment.

Regular check-ups and lab tests may be needed to monitor your response to the medication and ensure the proper functioning of your kidneys and liver. Always follow your doctor's instructions and recommendations for the safest and most effective treatment. If you experience any side effects or complications, seek medical attention immediately. 

<user> I heard that cyanocobalamin comes in different forms, and it's important to know which one is the best. can you explain how cyanocobalamin is converted in the body and why it's chosen as a manufactured form of vitamin b12? 

<assistant> Cyanocobalamin is a widely manufactured vitamer in the vitamin b12 family because it is the most air-stable form of the vitamin. It is the easiest to crystallize after being produced by bacterial fermentation, making it straightforward to purify. After consumption, the cyanide ligand in cyanocobalamin is replaced by other groups, such as adenosyl or methyl, to produce the biologically active forms of vitamin b12. The cyanide is then converted to thiocyanate and excreted by the kidneys.

In the body, animals, including humans, can convert cyanocobalamin to any of the active vitamin b12 compounds. These active forms are essential for various metabolic processes, including dna synthesis, fatty acid metabolism, and amino acid metabolism.

While cyanocobalamin itself is not active in the human body, it has the property of being easily converted into the forms our bodies need, such as methylcobalamin and adenosylcobalamin. These active forms are responsible for the numerous health benefits associated with vitamin b12.

Cyanocobalamin is chosen as a manufactured form of vitamin b12 because of its air-stability, ease of crystallization, and its ability to be transformed into active forms in the body. However, remember that it's always best to consult your healthcare provider before starting any vitamin b12 supplementation, as they can guide you on the best form and dosage tailored to your specific needs.

reference:
Cyanocobalamin is a manufactured form of vitamin  used to treat vitamin  deficiency. The deficiency may occur in pernicious anemia, following surgical removal of the stomach, with fish tapeworm, or due to bowel cancer. It is less preferred than hydroxocobalamin for treating vitamin  deficiency. It is used by mouth, by injection into a muscle, or as a nasal spray.

Cyanocobalamin is generally well tolerated. Minor side effects may include diarrhea and itchiness. Serious side effects may include anaphylaxis, low blood potassium, and heart failure. Use is not recommended in those who are allergic to cobalt or have Leber's disease. Vitamin  is an essential nutrient meaning that it cannot be made by the body but is required for life.

Cyanocobalamin was first manufactured in the 1940s. It is available as a generic medication and over the counter. In 2019, it was the 155th most commonly prescribed medication in the United States, with more than 4million prescriptions.

Medical use
Cyanocobalamin is usually prescribed after surgical removal of part or all of the stomach or intestine to ensure adequate serum levels of vitamin . It is also used to treat pernicious anemia, vitamin  deficiency (due to low intake from food or inability to absorb due to genetic or other factors), thyrotoxicosis, hemorrhage, malignancy, liver disease and kidney disease. Cyanocobalamin injections are often prescribed to gastric bypass patients who have had part of their small intestine bypassed, making it difficult for  to be acquired via food or vitamins. Cyanocobalamin is also used to perform the Schilling test to check ability to absorb vitamin .

Cyanocobalamin is also produced in the body (and then excreted via urine) after intravenous hydroxycobalamin is used to treat cyanide poisoning.

Side effects
Possible side effects of cyanocobalamin injection include allergic reactions such as hives, difficult breathing; redness of the face; swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles or lower legs; extreme thirst; and diarrhea. Less-serious side effects may include headache, dizziness, leg pain, itching, or rash.

Treatment of megaloblastic anemia with concurrent vitamin  deficiency using  vitamers (including cyanocobalamin), creates the possibility of hypokalemia due to increased erythropoiesis (red blood cell production) and consequent cellular uptake of potassium upon anemia resolution. When treated with cyanocobalamin, patients with Leber's disease may suffer serious optic atrophy, possibly leading to blindness.

Chemistry
Vitamin  is the "generic descriptor" name for any vitamers of vitamin . Animals, including humans, can convert cyanocobalamin to any one of the active vitamin  compounds.

Cyanocobalamin is one of the most widely manufactured vitamers in the vitamin  family (the family of chemicals that function as  when put into the body), because cyanocobalamin is the most air-stable of the  forms. It is the easiest to crystallize and therefore easiest to purify after it is produced by bacterial fermentation. It can be obtained as dark red crystals or as an amorphous red powder. Cyanocobalamin is hygroscopic in the anhydrous form, and sparingly soluble in water (1:80). It is stable to autoclaving for short periods at . The vitamin  coenzymes are unstable in light. After consumption the cyanide ligand is replaced by other groups (adenosyl, methyl) to produce the biologically active forms. The cyanide is converted to thiocyanate and excreted by the kidney.

Chemical reactions

In the cobalamins, cobalt normally exists in the trivalent state, Co(III). However, under reducing conditions, the cobalt center is reduced to Co(II) or even Co(I), which are usually denoted as  and , for reduced and super reduced, respectively.

<user> I heard about parexel international, an american biopharmaceutical services provider conducting clinical trials for drug approval processes. they're the second largest clinical research organization and have helped develop a large portion of top-selling biopharmaceuticals. i'm wondering about their history and growth, and how their work has impacted the pharmacology industry. can you provide me with a brief overview of their journey and some notable acquisitions they've made over the years? 

<assistant> Parexel international was founded in 1982 by josef von rickenbach and anne b. Sayigh to assist japanese and german firms in navigating the fda approval process. Over the years, they expanded organically and through 40 acquisitions. In the 1990s, the company grew internationally and established new practice areas, reaching 4,500 employees and 45 offices by 1999. They now have over 18,000 employees.

Their consulting and clinical trial work has contributed to the success of many popular drug brands and advancements in modern pharmacology. Some notable acquisitions include caspard consultants and sitebase clinical systems (june 1996), lansal clinical pharmaceutics and state and federal associates (august 1996), rescon and sheffield statistical services (march 1997), and kemper-masterson (december 1997). These additions enhanced their capabilities in various aspects of the industry. 

<user> That's interesting! recent acquisitions by parexel and their current ownership? 

<assistant> Certainly. In 2017, private equity firm pamplona capital management acquired parexel for approximately $5.0 billion. Then, on july 2, 2021, parexel entered into a merger agreement under which it would be acquired by eqt ix fund and goldman sachs for $8.5 billion. The acquisition was completed on november 15, 2021.

Throughout its history, parexel has undertaken various acquisitions to strengthen its position as a leading biopharmaceutical service provider. Some more recent acquisitions include:

1. In march 1998, parexel acquired pps europe limited, renamed parexel mms europe limited, a medical marketing company based in the united kingdom, and genesis pharma strategies limited, a physician-focused marketing and clinical communications firm catering to the international pharmaceutical industry. These companies were acquired for $113.1 million in common stock.
 
2. Also, in march 1998, parexel acquired mirai b.v., a full-service, pan-european contract research organization located in the netherlands, for $26 million in common stock.

3. Further, in march 1998, they acquired logos gmbh, a provider of regulatory services to pharmaceutical manufacturers, for $3.9 million in common stock.

These acquisitions expanded parexel's presence in different geographical locations, added new service offerings, and enhanced their capabilities in medical marketing, physician-focused marketing, clinical communications, and regulatory services. The combination of parexel's organic growth and acquisition strategy enabled them to stay competitive and meet the changing needs of the pharmaceutical and biotechnology industries.

Today, under the new ownership of eqt ix fund and goldman sachs, parexel continues to provide clinical trial and consulting services to the top 50 biopharmaceutical and top 30 biotechnology companies, contributing to ongoing advancements in pharmaceuticals and biotechnology. 

<user> Thanks for the informative response. i noticed that parexel publishes the annual parexel r&d statistical sourcebook and operates the parexel-academy. can you shed some light on the purpose of these two initiatives and how they influence the biopharmaceutical industry? 

<assistant> The parexel r&d statistical sourcebook is an annual publication that serves as a comprehensive resource for r&d trends, statistics, and insights in the biopharmaceutical industry. It provides valuable data and analysis to industry professionals for making informed decisions, conducting research, and staying up-to-date with the latest developments across the industry.

On the other hand, the parexel-academy is an educational initiative that offers various courses, workshops, and training programs designed to develop the skills required for a successful career in clinical research and related fields. The academy aims to create a pool of well-trained professionals that can contribute effectively to the biopharmaceutical industry.

Both initiatives play an essential role in advancing the biopharmaceutical sector by providing valuable knowledge and resources. The r&d statistical sourcebook helps drive evidence-based decisions in research and development, while the parexel-academy ensures a competent workforce is available to drive innovation and the successful execution of clinical trials.

It is the second largest clinical research organization in the world and has helped develop approximately 95% of the 200 top-selling biopharmaceuticals on the market today. The company publishes the annual Parexel R&D Statistical Sourcebook, operates the Parexel-Academy, and councils all of the top 50 biopharmaceutical and top 30 biotechnology companies.

Parexel was founded in 1982 by Josef von Rickenbach and organic chemist Anne B. Sayigh initially to advise Japanese and German firms on how to navigate the FDA approval process. The firm has grown organically over the years and through 40 acquisitions. Josef von Rickenbach is credited with establishing Parexel's culture and practices based on the principles he experienced as a researcher at Schering-Plough in Lucerne, Switzerland, before leaving the company upon retiring in 2018.

In 1990, the firm expanded internationally and established new practice areas. By 1999 it had a staff of 4,500 and 45 offices.  In the 2000s, it grew to over 18,000 employees. Parexel's consulting and clinical trial work has helped establish many household drug brands and contributed to numerous successes in modern pharmacology.

The company was acquired by private equity firm Pamplona Capital Management for approximately $5.0 billion. The deal closed in September 2017.On July 2, 2021, Parexel announced a merger agreement under which it would be acquired by EQT IX fund and Goldman Sachs for $8.5 billion. Acquisition history

 Sitebase Clinical Systems, Inc., a provider of remote data entry technology designed to enhance the quality and timeliness of clinical trial data.
 August 1996: Parexel acquires in separate transactions for a combined 1,008,304 own shares of common stock:
Lansal Clinical Pharmaceutics, Limited, a contract research organization located in Israel, and
 State and Federal Associates, Inc., a Washington, D.C.-based provider of medical marketing and related consulting services to the health care and pharmaceutical industries.

RESCON, Inc. a medical marketing business located in the Washington, D.C. area, and
 Sheffield Statistical Services, Ltd., a company located in the United Kingdom that specializes in biostatistical analysis.
 November 1997: Parexel acquires substantially all of the assets of Hayden Image Processing Group, a Colorado corporation developing software for analyzing and measuring high resolution medical images, and announces its strategic alliance with The IRIS Group S.A. based in Belgium, specializing in intelligent optical character recognition technology.
 December 1997: Parexel acquires Kemper-Masterson, Inc, a management consulting firm on FDA and other regulatory matters to the pharmaceutical, biotechnology and medical device industries based in Massachusetts.
 March 1998: Parexel acquires four companies:
PPS Europe Limited, subsequently renamed Parexel MMS Europe Limited, a medical marketing firm based in the United Kingdom, and Genesis Pharma Strategies Limited, a physician-focused marketing and clinical communications firm servicing the international pharmaceutical industry, for $113.1 million in own common stock;
MIRAI B.V., a full service, pan-European contract research organization based in the Netherlands, for $26 million in own common stock;
LOGOS GmbH, a provider of regulatory services to pharmaceutical manufacturers, for $3.9 million in own common stock.

dialogue:
<user> I recently underwent a chest x-ray and the doctor found a small nodule in my lung. i'm a bit worried about what it could be and how it might affect my health. can you give me an overview of lung nodules and the possible causes? what factors might indicate whether it's benign or malignant? 

<assistant> A lung nodule, also known as a pulmonary nodule, is a small focal density in the lung. It's usually smaller than three centimeters in diameter, and may occur as a solitary pulmonary nodule (spn) or in multiples.

In most cases, lung nodules are benign and could represent a granuloma, hamartoma, or other non-cancerous growths. However, in about 20% of cases, they may represent malignant cancer, especially in older adults and smokers.

Several factors can help in determining the nature of a lung nodule. These include size, location, margin morphology, presence of multiple nodules, growth rate, presence of emphysema or fibrosis, and characteristics observed in radiological imaging. It's important to follow up with your doctor and possibly conduct further tests to properly assess the nature of the nodule. 

<user> What are some common benign causes of lung nodules? i know you mentioned granuloma and hamartoma, but i'm curious if there are other possibilities as well. also, how do the risk factors for incidentally discovered nodules, like size and location, affect the probability of cancer? are there specific signs in radiological imaging that suggest a higher likelihood of malignancy in a pulmonary nodule? 

<assistant> Apart from granuloma and hamartoma, various benign causes of lung nodules include infections like tuberculosis, fungal infections (e.g., coccidioidomycosis), lung abscess, pneumonia, and rarer infections like nocardial infection or worm infestations. Immune disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis, granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and organizing pneumonia, can also lead to lung nodules.

Some risk factors affecting the probability of a nodule being cancerous are:

1. Size: larger nodules have a higher risk of cancer.
2. Location: upper lobe location increases cancer risk, but proximity to fissures or pleura may indicate a benign cause.
3. Margin morphology: spiculated margins are a risk factor for cancer.
4. Multiplicity: up to 3 additional nodules increase cancer risk, but 4 or more decreases it.
5. Growth rate: solid cancers have typical doubling times of 100-400 days while subsolid cancers take 3-5 years.
6. Presence of emphysema or fibrosis: these are risk factors for cancer.

In radiological imaging, certain characteristics can suggest a higher likelihood of malignancy, such as spiculations (highly predictive of cancer), pleural retraction, irregular or lobulated margins, and thicker walls in the case of central cavities. However, these factors should be assessed by a medical professional alongside other clinical information to make an accurate determination. 

<user> Are there any treatment options or follow-up techniques to monitor lung nodules and help distinguish between benign and malignant growths? 

<assistant> Yes, there are several follow-up techniques and treatment options that can help monitor lung nodules and differentiate between benign and malignant growths. The course of action primarily depends on the individual's risk factors and the characteristics of the lung nodule.

1. Observation and monitoring: for low-risk patients with small nodules, periodic monitoring with chest x-rays or ct scans may be advised. This helps determine any changes in nodule size or appearance, which could indicate malignancy.

2. Non-invasive imaging: contrast-enhanced ct scans or pet scans can assess factors like enhancement and metabolic activity, which can help differentiate between benign and malignant nodules.

3. Biopsy: if there's a high suspicion of cancer, biopsy techniques such as fine needle aspiration, core needle biopsy, or video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (vats) may be performed to obtain tissue samples for analysis.

4. Surgical resection: for nodules highly suggestive of malignancy or when biopsy is inconclusive, surgical removal may be considered to confirm the diagnosis and remove the potential cancer.

5. Additional tests: blood tests and pulmonary function tests might also be conducted to better understand the individual's overall health and risk factors.

It's crucial to consult with your doctor to identify the most appropriate approach based on your specific findings and risk factors. They will guide you in determining the best course of action for monitoring and treating the lung nodule. 

<user> How common are incidentally discovered lung nodules on chest x-rays and ct scans? 

<assistant> Lung nodules are incidentally discovered in a fairly small percentage of chest x-rays and ct scans. One or more lung nodules can be an incidental finding in up to 0.2% of chest x-rays and around 1% of ct scans.

The higher sensitivity of ct scans compared to chest x-rays means they are more likely to detect small nodules that might otherwise remain unnoticed. However, the vast majority of these incidentally discovered nodules turn out to be benign, representing non-cancerous growths or other medical conditions.

Despite the low incidence rate, it's important to adequately evaluate and follow up on incidentally discovered lung nodules, especially for those who have risk factors for lung cancer, such as a history of smoking, exposure to asbestos, or other carcinogens. Monitoring these nodules and addressing any suspicious findings with appropriate testing and interventions can help ensure early detection and treatment of lung cancer, if present, and can significantly improve the prognosis.

It is essential to discuss any concerns or findings with your doctor, who can interpret the radiological images and provide a professional assessment, taking into account your medical history, risk factors, and the appearance and characteristics of the nodules.

<assistant> A lung nodule, also known as a pulmonary nodule, is a small focal density in the lung. It's usually smaller than three centimeters in diameter, and may occur as a solitary pulmonary nodule (spn) or in multiples.

Several factors can help in determining the nature of a lung nodule. These include size, location, margin morphology, presence of multiple nodules, growth rate, presence of emphysema or fibrosis, and characteristics observed in radiological imaging. reference:
A lung nodule or pulmonary nodule is a relatively small focal density in the lung. A solitary pulmonary nodule (SPN) or coin lesion, is a mass in the lung smaller than three centimeters in diameter. A pulmonary micronodule has a diameter of less than three millimetres. There may also be multiple nodules.

One or more lung nodules can be an incidental finding found in up to 0.2% of chest X-rays and around 1% of CT scans.

The nodule most commonly represents a benign tumor such as a granuloma or hamartoma, but in around 20% of cases it represents a malignant cancer, especially in older adults and smokers. Conversely, 10 to 20% of patients with lung cancer are diagnosed in this way. If the patient has a history of smoking or the nodule is growing, the possibility of cancer may need to be excluded through further radiological studies and interventions, possibly including surgical resection. The prognosis depends on the underlying condition.

Causes
Not every round spot on a radiological image is a solitary pulmonary nodule: it may be confused with the projection of a structure of the chest wall or skin, such as a nipple, a healing rib fracture or electrocardiographic monitoring.

The most important cause to exclude is any form of lung cancer, including rare forms such as primary pulmonary lymphoma, carcinoid tumor and a solitary metastasis to the lung (common unrecognised primary tumor sites are melanomas, sarcomas or testicular cancer). Benign tumors in the lung include hamartomas and chondromas.

The most common benign coin lesion is a granuloma (inflammatory nodule), for example due to tuberculosis or a fungal infection, such as Coccidioidomycosis. Other infectious causes include a lung abscess, pneumonia (including pneumocystis pneumonia) or rarely nocardial infection or worm infection (such as dirofilariasis or dog heartworm infestation). Lung nodules can also occur in immune disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis or granulomatosis with polyangiitis, or organizing pneumonia.

A solitary lung nodule can be found to be an arteriovenous malformation, a hematoma or an infarction zone. It may also be caused by bronchial atresia, sequestration, an inhaled foreign body or pleural plaque.

Risk factors
Risk factors for incidentally discovered nodules are mainly:
 General risk factors of lung cancer such as exposure to tobacco smoking or other carcinogens such as asbestos and previously diagnosed cancer, respiratory infections, or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
 Size: larger size confers a higher risk of cancer

 Location: Upper lobe location is a risk factor for cancer, while a location close to a fissure or the pleura indicates a benign lymph node, especially if having a triangular shape.
 Margin morphology: a spiculated margin is a risk factor for cancer. Benign causes tend to have a well defined border, whereas lobulated lesions or those with an irregular margin extending into the neighbouring tissue tend to be malignant. In particular, spiculations are highly predictive of malignancy with a positive predictive value up to 90%.  Also, a "notch sign", which is an abrupt indentation of the nodule, increases the risk of cancer, but may also be found in granulomatous diseases.

 Multiplicity: Where the presence of up to an additional 3 nodules has been found to increase the risk of cancer, but decrease in case of 4 or more additional ones, likely because it indicates a previous granulomatous infection rather than cancer.
 Growth rate: solid cancers generally doubles in volume over between 100 and 400 days, while subsolid cancers (generally representing adenocarcinomas) generally doubles in volume over 3 to 5 years. One volume doubling equals approximately a 26% increase in diameter.
 Presence of emphysema and/or fibrosis is a risk factor for cancer. In comparison, the typical size doubling are less than 20 days for infections, and more than 400 days for benign nodules.
 Enhancement: If the exam is done as a combined non-contrast and contrast CT, a solitary nodule with an enhancement off less than 15 Hounsfield units (HU), whereas a higher enhancement indicates a malignant tumor (with a sensitivity estimated at 98%).
 Areas of fatty tissue (−40 to −120 HU) indicates a hamartoma. However, only about 50% of hamartomas are fat containing.
 If there is a central cavity, then a thin wall points to a benign cause whereas a thick wall is associated with malignancy (especially 4 mm or less versus 16 mm or more).

 In case of calcifications, a popcorn-like appearance indicates a hamartoma, which is benign.
 In case of subsolid nodules, being part solid has a higher risk of cancer than being purely ground glass opacity.

 Pleural retraction is far more common in cancers.

It's usually smaller than three centimeters in diameter, and may occur as a solitary pulmonary nodule (spn) or in multiples.<>
In most cases, lung nodules are benign and could represent a granuloma, hamartoma, or other non-cancerous growths.<>
However, in about 20% of cases, they may represent malignant cancer, especially in older adults and smokers.<>
Several factors can help in determining the nature of a lung nodule.<>
These include size, location, margin morphology, presence of multiple nodules, growth rate, presence of emphysema or fibrosis, and characteristics observed in radiological imaging.<>
It's important to follow up with your doctor and possibly conduct further tests to properly assess the nature of the nodule.<>

dialogue:
<user> 2010 itm cup season and its format? 

<assistant> The 2010 itm cup season was the fifth season since the competition was restructured in 2006, involving the top 14 provincial unions of new zealand. The tournament was won by canterbury, who defeated waikato 33-13 in the competition final. The competition was sponsored by itm for the first time, making it the 34th season of new zealand's premier domestic competition overall.

The competition format covered a 15-week schedule, including a total of 91 matches. The top seven sides became part of the top table, known as the premiership, while the bottom seven sides formed the championship. The regular season consisted of 13 matches, with each team playing all other provincial unions consecutively. Additionally, each team played six home and seven away, or seven home and six away matches.

After the regular season, the top four teams advanced to the semi-finals. The top two winners, based on table points, received a home semi-final. In the first round of the finals, the semi-finals, the first-placed winner hosted the fourth-placed winner and the second-placed winner hosted the third-placed winner. The final was hosted by the top remaining seed.

The competition used a point system for standings, including 4 points for a win, 2 points for a draw, 1 bonus point for a loss by seven points or less, and 1 bonus point for scoring four or more tries in a match. Teams were ranked based on log points, tiebreakers, and other factors. 

<user> What were some notable moments from the season? 

<assistant> The 2010 itm cup season had several memorable moments. Here are a few:

1. In round 4, tasman secured their first-ever victory against canterbury.
2. In round 8, southland achieved its first-ever win against waikato in hamilton, and taranaki rugby union celebrated their 125th anniversary with a victory over canterbury in new plymouth.
3. In round 9, southland won their first-ever ranfurly shield game against auckland and their first victory against auckland since 1971. Also in this round, the canterbury vs. Wellington match was offered free of charge in response to the canterbury earthquake of 4 september, attracting the largest crowd of the season (30,000).
4. In round 10, manawatu achieved their first-ever win against tasman.

These are just a few highlights from an exciting season of provincial rugby in new zealand. 

<user> Can you give more details about the points system and the classification process? 

<assistant> The points system and classification process for the 2010 itm cup season were as follows:

1. Points breakdown:
- 4 points were awarded for a win.
   - 2 points were awarded for a draw.
   - 1 bonus point was awarded for a loss by seven points or less.
   - 1 bonus point was awarded for scoring four or more tries in a match.

2. Overall standings classification system:
- four division winners/leaders in log points order.
   - the remaining three teams in log points order.
   When teams were level on log points, they were differentiated by the following criteria:
A. The winner of the round-robin match between the two provinces.
     B. The highest overall points difference.
     C. The highest number of tries scored.
     D. The highest number of points scored.
     E. A coin toss, if all other criteria were equal.

The system was designed to reward teams for their performance both in winning matches and being competitive in close matches. The bonus points allowed for more dynamic standings and encouraged teams to play attacking rugby in order to score four or more tries. 

<user> Can you share some information on the pre-season challenges and the ranfurly shield during the 2010 itm cup season? 

<assistant> Unfortunately, the provided information doesn't specify the pre-season challenges or details of the ranfurly shield for the 2010 itm cup season. However, i can tell you that the ranfurly shield is a prestigious trophy in new zealand rugby, often referred to as the "log o' wood." it has a challenge format, meaning that during the rugby season, the holder of the shield must defend it in challenge matches against other provincial teams. A team that defeats the current holder takes possession of the shield and must then defend it in future matches. The shield matches often bring high levels of excitement and passion among rugby fans in new zealand. If you're interested in learning more, i would recommend looking up specific sources that focus on the pre-season challenges and the ranfurly shield during the 2010 itm cup season.

<user> Japanese swimmer who specializes in individual medley, butterfly, breaststroke, and freestyle events? i'm interested in knowing about his achievements in world championships and other swimming events, along with his world records and titles. it would be great if you could provide some details about his swimming career, experiences in international competitions, and significant milestones achieved throughout his journey. 

<assistant> Of course! The japanese swimmer you're referring to is daiya seto. Seto is an accomplished professional swimmer who began taking up swimming at the age of five. His specialties are individual medley, butterfly, breaststroke, and freestyle events.

In 2012, seto burst onto the international scene after winning the gold medal in the 400-metre individual medley at the world short course championships. He set an asian record at that time as well. Following this, seto continued to excel in international competitions, winning gold in the same event at the short course world championships in 2014, 2016, 2018, and 2021.

At the long course world championships, seto won gold in the 400-metre individual medley in 2013, 2015, and 2019. His performance at the 2018 world short course championships was particularly noteworthy, as he set a new world record in the 200-metre butterfly with a time of 1:48.24.

Seto also participated in the 2016 summer olympics in rio de janeiro, where he earned a bronze medal in the 400-metre individual medley. Furthermore, in 2018, seto was named "male asian swimmer of the year" by swimswam.

In addition to his successes at world championships, seto has shone at other international competitions, such as the pan pacific championships, where he won gold medals in 2014 and 2018. He was also a member of the inaugural season of the international swimming league, swimming for the energy standard swim club, which won the team title in las vegas in 2019. In the same competition, seto set a new world record in the 400-metre individual medley with a time of 3:54.81, breaking the former record set by ryan lochte of the united states.

At the 2020 fina champions swim series in beijing, seto set a new asian and japan national record in the long course 200-metre butterfly with a time of 1:52.53. Seto took part in the 2020 summer olympics in tokyo, where he finished fourth in the 200-metre individual medley and didn't qualify for the 400-metre individual medley final. 

<user> It's impressive how he started swimming at such a young age. seto's early years? for example, his journey leading up to the 2012 japan olympic team selection and his performance in the 2012 fina swimming world cup.
